Tate spectra

Feb 26, 2019

Let be an even-periodic refinement of a Deligne-Mumford stack arising via Lurie’s theorem, and assume that the map is affine. Let denote the associated oriented spectral (also see here) -divisible group over , with underlying -divisible group , say of height (so that is -local). A classical computation shows that if , where is a height Morava -theory, then .

This is not true, however, if . Indeed, in this case, if , then is the -torsion in the formal group associated to . The height formal group is actually the formal component of the -divisible group of height ; this is defined via the canonical map . Note that is precisely the restriction of to the locus .

In general, if is as above, let . Then there is a map . Let denote the origin of , defined coordinate-independently as follows: there is a quotient map , and this induces a closed immersion . Let denote the canonical even-periodic refinement of the associated open subscheme (really, substack) of . There is an analogous construction one can do for : let denote the -dimensional complex (-dimensional real) representation of given by the inclusion of the th roots of unity. Then the inclusion defines a map , which in turn defines a map . We then have the following lemma, whose proof we shall postpone.

Lemma: For some , there is an equivariant identification of -modules.

The -ring necessarily has some even period (which can be proved by arguing exactly as in our proof of the above lemma (to be given below); some power of the periodicity generator in identifying survives the descent spectral sequence), so we can then choose large enough such that ; in this case, defines a map . Let denote the colimit; then, it is known that is equivalent to the Tate construction . The discussion above implies that the map restricts to a map .

We then have the following blueshift phenomenon; see also Theorem 3.4 here for the local case of Lubin-Tate theory with replaced by a general finite abelian -group and the Tate construction replaced by the geometric fixed points construction:

Theorem: The maximum height of the formal component of the -divisible group over every geometric point of is at most ; in other words, the canonical map factors through .

This implies that is -local; because of the ring map , we conclude that is also -local.

Here’s the proof of the theorem. For every field , we know that , where is the height of the formal component of . It follows that the maximum height of the formal component of the -divisible group over every geometric point of is the largest integer for which there is a nontrivial homomorphism . (One could see this as the statement that an -point of is the data of a -divisible group over isomorphic to the pullback of to , along with a -torsion point, possibly zero. Removing the identity of precisely excludes this degeneracy.) Clearly is the largest such integer, so we win.

What can we do with our understanding of ? Above, we constructed a map . The target may be thought of as a natural target of cohomology operations. Namely, we have a map , where is the transfer ideal; this map is the total power operation. Now, , and there is a natural map to , which in turn maps to . The map t; this map is the total power operation. Now, , and there is a natural map to , which in turn maps to . The map to factors through the quotient , because, in a sense, is the homotopical version of this quotient. The upshot is that we obtain a map .

There is also a map of -ring spectra ; this is called the Tate-valued Frobenius. This map is discussed in great detail in this paper. The above discussion then suggests that there is a map of -rings factoring the Tate-valued Frobenius. Since , it is most natural to expect that this comes from a morphism . I haven’t yet gotten around to precisely defining this map, but it is supposed to be analogous to the morphism that is the pullback of the morphism that sends to . The desired map is a bit mysterious: it’s definitely not going to be a spectral lift of the map : the main theorems of this paper of mine forbid the source from being lifted to the world of -rings.

Instead, (I believe that) the derived stack classifies a different, but related, moduli problem. Recall that the classical stack classifies the following moduli problem: a map is the data of a -torsion point on the -divisible group defined by the pullback of to along the map . In the spectral setting, a morphism (now from a derived scheme ) certainly still defines a spectral -divisible group over via the pullback of along the map , but what is the appropriate notion of a -torsion point on ? Let us consider the case when both and are actually affine, so that is an affine group scheme over . Presumably the derived stack classifies a “-torsion point” on . This would be a map of constant group schemes . In particular, we have a -torsion element of the underlying -divisible group over the underlying scheme of .

In general, if is an -ring and is a strictly commutative element of , i.e., an element of such that the map detecting factors through , we may take the quotient , and this is an -ring. Indeed, since there is a fiber sequence , we get an equivalence . In particular, if is a finitely generated ideal of generated by strictly commutative elements, then is a closed subscheme of . Weil divisors on Noetherian schemes whose associated ideal sheaves are generated by strictly commutative elements therefore give closed subschemes of that deserve to be called Weil divisors of . In particular, given a strict -torsion point on defined by a morphism , we can form the closed subscheme of as the Weil divisor in defined as the Weil divisor associated to the morphism of ordinary group schemes. Using this, one should be able to define the map as a map of moduli problems. I haven’t had the time to work this out precisely, but I think the story should work out similarly to the classical theory.

We now prove the lemma we left unproved way back in the beginning of the post. Let denote the global sections of some etale cover of , so that is even-periodic. Then it is classical that , so by descent, it suffices to construct a map of -modules which is an equivalence after inducing up to . This is the same as an element of which maps to the obvious class in .

We know (because it is true after pulling back via every affine etale morphism) that there is an equivalence of sheaves . This defines a section of the homotopy sheaf . Using the Bousfield-Kan spectral sequence, one can construct the following analogue of the descent spectral sequence for -graded homotopy groups (where the action is trivial; the construction becomes more complicated when a nontrivial action is involved):

where is the sheaf on and . We have an element ; we claim that there is some for which survives to the -page of this spectral sequence; then, defines an element of that by construction maps to the obvious element of , as desired.

Suppose that is torsion for . Then is -torsion for some , so by the Leibniz rule, survives to the -page. Arguing similarly, we conclude that for each , some power of survives to the -page. To conclude, it suffices to show that degenerates at a finite page. This is true by thick subcategory arguments: by tameness of the map , the stack (which has an even-periodic refinement to ) is tame, and hence has finite cohomological dimension. Therefore, the spectral sequence for already degenerates a finite page. By the Hopkins-Ravenel smash product theorem, is in the thick tensor ideal generated by ; therefore, we conclude that the spectral sequence for degenerates at a finite page.

It therefore remains to show that is torsion for . The map is affine, so the map is also affine. It follows that is the quotient of an affine scheme by , which proves that has no higher sheaf cohomology; in particular, must be torsion for , and we win.
